summary: This is a Department of Justice afternoon news digest from April 14, 2020, summarizing headlines and news articles across various topics including COVID-19, federal law enforcement, and legal cases. It contains a brief update on a Jeffrey Epstein victim's failed legal challenge to his 2007 non-prosecution agreement and a mention of a withdrawn defamation lawsuit by a Harvard professor related to Epstein.

persons.name: Courtney Wild
persons.context: Lost her bid to challenge Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution deal with federal prosecutors in Florida, according to a court ruling mentioned in the digest.

persons.name: Lawrence Lessig
persons.context: Withdrew a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times concerning an article about his views toward Jeffrey Epstein, after the newspaper made changes to the online article.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in two news items: one regarding a victim's failed legal challenge to his 2007 plea deal, and another regarding a withdrawn defamation lawsuit by a Harvard professor related to him.

connections.description: Wild is identified as a victim of Epstein who filed a legal challenge to his non-prosecution agreement.
Lessig was the subject of a New York Times article concerning views toward accepting donations from Epstein, which led to a defamation lawsuit.

events.title: Court denies Epstein victim's challenge to plea deal
events.description: A court ruled against Courtney Wild's bid to challenge the non-prosecution agreement Jeffrey Epstein made with federal prosecutors in Florida in 2007.

events.title: Lawrence Lessig withdraws defamation lawsuit
events.description: Harvard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig withdrew a lawsuit accusing The New York Times of defamation concerning an article about his views toward Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein made a non-prosecution deal with federal prosecutors in Florida, allowing him to avoid federal sex trafficking charges and plead guilty to lesser state charges.

keyFacts: On April 14, 2020, a court ruled against Jeffrey Epstein victim Courtney Wild's attempt to challenge his 2007 non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors in Florida.
Harvard Law School professor Lawrence Lessig withdrew a defamation lawsuit against The New York Times related to an article about his views on accepting donations from Jeffrey Epstein.
The document is a DOJ news digest primarily focused on COVID-19 and general legal news, with only brief, passing mentions of Epstein-related cases.
